awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Opportunity to acquire continuous, high-resolution geochemical proxies for paleoclimate, paleoenvironment, and modern hydrogeology from CPCP cores
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will generate a continuous record of chemical composition changes through rock cores collected in Petrified Forest National Park as part of the NSF-funded Colorado Plateau Coring Project. The study has three main objectives, 1) to develop an understanding of how changes in the chemistry of sediments reflect changes in past climate from 200-million-year-old river and flood plain systems, 2) to use this record to develop an understanding of the influence of both CO2 and changes in Earth’s orbital parameters on past climatic variations and 3) develop a chemical dataset that will provide a baseline understanding of the distribution of potential ground water contaminants (e.g., As, U) in adjacent lands of the Navajo Nation and surrounding regions that draw water from the cored strata. The data generated in this project will serve as the basis of a project for a 2022 summer REU student from Navajo Technical University. In addition, this project will support two early career scientists and two Columbia University graduate students. Finally, the project team will develop curriculum and outreach products through the Rutgers Geology Museum and facilitate synergistic activities on related environmental issues in New Jersey and Colorado Plateau regions. 

The Triassic Chinle and Moenkopi Formations occupy huge areas of the Colorado Plateau and record the history of Triassic environmental change on an immense alluvial plain and are famous for their fossil record of the evolution of continental ecosystems including dinosaurs and mammals. The physical, paleomagnetic, and geochronological stratigraphy of CPCP-1 cores has been described in a suite of recent papers and placed into a larger paleoenvironmental and global temporal context, but the chemical stratigraphy of the cores has yet to be analyzed. Several small projects have demonstrated the utility of such data, but the lack of synoptic chemical datasets from these cores hinders their potential for both paleo- and modern (including their impact on groundwater) environmental analysis. This project will fill this deficit with the acquisition of continuous XRF chemical data that will permit tests of hypotheses of orbital pacing of climate (long eccentricity and inclination cycles) as recorded in these strata and of how cyclical climate and the deep time hydrological history of these strata relates to present stratigraphic distribution of potential geogenic contaminants and their migration into present day aquifers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of this project was to fill a gap in the characterization of cores collected during the first phase of the Colorado Plateau Coring Project (CPCP-1, 2013) by using an XRF core scanning platform to produce a comprehensive, major and trace element characterization of ~850 m of rock core from Petrified Forest National Park. We used this continuous geochemical record to better understand the range of processes that shaped the Late Triassic environments in this region, including the role of astronomically paced climate, and developed a framework to develop mechanistic models of how the integrated geologic history of the region structures its modern hydrogeologic properties. In addition to new chemical and mineralogical datasets we produced during this project, we began the process of integrating unprocessed legacy computed tomography (CT) data from the cores to better understand their physical properties. A notable outcome of this project was the development of new methods to rapidly map the distribution of important metals (e.g., As, U) that exist as geogenic contaminants within bedrock aquifer systems across the region and understand the conditions that favor their release into or removal from the environment. When applied at the appropriate spatial scale, and integrated with field mapping, groundwater sampling, and hydrologic models, these methods have the potential to enhance predictive models on exposure risk related to their release in groundwater supplies or through airborne transport. The application of this conceptual framework comprises a large fraction of the science goals of the second phase of the Colorado Plateau Coring Project (CPCP-2), recently recommended for full funding by the International Continental Scientific Drilling Program. In collaboration with co-PI RoyChowdhury at Navajo Technical University we are working on well remediation strategies as part of these efforts. 

In an experiential learning setting using state-of-the-art instrumentation, we provided training in basic geoscience principles, spectroscopy, data analysis/interpretation to nine undergraduate and four PhD-level graduate students. Numerous student-led projects have led to the submission (and subsequent presentation) of fourteen conference abstracts with three manuscripts currently in preparation for publication at the time of this report. This model facilitated numerous peer and near-peer mentoring opportunities and provided first time research experiences to several students. The informal partnership developed between Navajo Technical University and Rutgers University during this project has led to efforts to secure support to formalize, expand, and integrate it more fully with the department to provide educational pathways for NTU students to start as interns and end with MS or PhDs from Rutgers. NTU student Chase Bebo received multiple awards for his work as a part of this project, placing 2nd at both the 2022 NTU Research Day (oral) and American Indian Higher Education Consortium (poster) competitions. An INTERN supplement to this project provided the opportunity for graduate student Clara Chang to develop methods in applied spectroscopy to address problems at the intersection of environmental science and public health. Three students involved in this project received graduate or postdoctoral fellowships to continue and expand work initiated and developed during this project, and all undergraduates who received training have either continued their education in graduate school or are successfully employed in the geosciences. We have shared the implications of our research with relevant stakeholders across the region, including Petrified Forest National Park Officials and members of the Navajo Nation, and through our continue work in the region, we will highlight the importance of understanding the vertical and lateral distribution of geogenic contaminants in the bedrock environment as an important parameter in quantifying exposure risk. 

 


Last Modified: 10/21/2024
Modified by: Kenneth G Miller
